translator_notes: This is the final page of the Table of Contents, listing chapters 75-80 and three appendices
河东狮 (Tigress from East of the River) is a classical allusion to a shrewish wife, from a Tang dynasty anecdote about Liu Zongyuan
中山狼 (Wolf from Zhongshan) alludes to an ungrateful person who turns on their benefactor, from a Ming dynasty fable
姽婳词 refers to poems about beautiful women, specifically about heroic women in this context
芙蓉诔 (Elegy for the Hibiscus) is Baoyu's famous lament for Qingwen, one of the novel's most literary passages
水月 (Water and Moon) refers to Buddhist concepts of illusion and impermanence
靖藏本 is a lost manuscript known only through Mao Guoyao's transcribed commentary
research_notes: The 80-chapter version ends here - this is the authentic Cao Xueqin text
Chapters 79 and 80 share the same title, indicating the chapter division was somewhat fluid
The appendices provide crucial textual scholarship on the manuscript tradition
